author: Special Correspondent
text:
The final hour of the last session of the 13th Kerala Legislative Assembly saw Chief Minister Oommen Chandy fervently protesting his innocence on the floor of the House.

There was a slight tremor in his voice when he faced the empty Opposition benches and emphatically stated, “I do not want to go out shamed.”

“I would have not continued in office for a moment had there been an iota of truth in the slanderous allegations hurled against me. My conscience is clear. The prayers of the people and the unstinted support of my Cabinet, party and coalition saw me go forward in the face of such relentless attacks,” he said.

“The last session of the 13th Assembly would have been historic had it not been for the Opposition’s strident positions. Their continuous boycotts and hollow sloganeering turned the session into something nobody would like to remember,” he said.

The “mind numbing emptiness of the Opposition benches” had rendered legislative business impossible, he said.

The CM said he was “laughing in my mind” when the Opposition brought up the two-decade old palmolien import graft case against him in the Assembly again. “They were in power two times and it is their incapability that I still remain a witness in the case,” he said.

Mr. Chandy’s final speech as leader of the House was also a call to his supporters to prepare for the electoral battle ahead. “We are going to the people’s court with a clear conscience. Let people sit in judgment of our government,” he said.
title: My conscience is clear: CM
